awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, the Renewable Energy Materials Scholars STEM (REMS-STEM) project is providing support to low-income students with demonstrated financial need and academic promise to succeed in STEM disciplines at Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI). REMS-STEM will contribute to the important work of providing new pathways for students entering the STEM workforce with undergraduate degrees.  Specifically, this project will provide scholarships to 20 low-income, academically-talented, underrepresented students who transfer from community colleges to WPI to complete bachelor's degrees in the field of renewable energy materials. Expected outcomes of this S-STEM Track 2 project include an exemplary degree attainment rate for REMS-STEM scholars (90% in two years and 100% in three years)and an increase in the number of low-income students who attain employment or pursue graduate research in a clean energy technology field.  

The primary goal of the project is to overcome the known barriers to community college students in completing a four-year degree in STEM education. REMS-STEM will provide wrap-around support services to funded students, including: a combined approach towards curriculum enrichment; applied research opportunities; hierarchical mentoring; and career-development services. The REMS-STEM program will provide enhanced career development support by including entrepreneurial mindset training through a student-centered pedagogy and by facilitating the access of REMS-STEM scholars to a network of national and regional partnerships. The project will rely on existing WPI support systems but also provide a significant faculty mentoring program for REMS-STEM scholars. The project will produce knowledge about the effectiveness of the supports for the S-STEM scholars, particularly in the area of mentoring, where the faculty will mentor advanced students who will mentor early undergraduate students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the Renewable Energy Materials Scholars STEM (REMS-STEM) Program at Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI), was to recruit, retain, and support low-income, academically talented, underrepresented students who transfer from two-year institutions of higher education (i.e., community colleges) to WPI, to complete a bachelor’s degree in the field of renewable energy materials.

The key objectives of the REMS-STEM program were: 

(1) A 90% two-year graduation rate (18/20 REMS-STEM scholars), compared to the average 2-year graduation rate for transfer students of 33%.

(2) Ensuring that the remaining REMS-STEM scholars that do not graduate in two years will graduate in their third year, making a 3-year graduation rate of 100% vs. the current average 74%.

(3) Increasing the level of socioeconomic and racial diversity among students at WPI.

(4) Improving the probability that a REMS-STEM graduate will attain employment in a clean-energy technology field or continue their education at the graduate level.

Key Results of the REMS-STEM program:

(1) Recruited 21 (initially 20 total were proposed) low-income, academically talented, underrepresented students mainly from our two-year partner community colleges Quinsigamond Community College (QCC) and Mount Wachusett Community College (MWCC) to pursue a bachelor’s degree at WPI with a focus on renewable energy.

(2) Partnered with local two-year colleges with strong STEM programs. We strengthen our relationship with QCC and MWCC by organizing visits for the undergraduate students at WPI, facilitating research opportunities in the research labs at WPI, and holding information sessions about the REMS-STEM program. 

(3) Retained and graduated 90% of REMS-STEM scholars in two-years, and 95% in three-years, by providing them with wrap-around support services, that included a combined approach of curriculum enrichment, applied research opportunities, academic and research mentoring, and career-development services; 50% of the REMS-STEM recruited students were women and underrepresented minorities, which contributes to increasing the diversity in the engineering workforce fields, particularly the renewable energy field.

(4) Enhanced career sustainability of REMS-STEM scholars through their enrollment in graduate studies (MS and PhD) at WPI and elsewhere, and in career opportunities through industry partnerships in a clean energy technology field. 

The results were actively disseminated by the PI and CO-PIs at national and international conferences and students involved in research presented their results at national conferences and were part of peer review publication authorship. All students completed two major projects at WPI with full/partial concentration on clean energy, an Intermediate Qualifying Project (IQP) that focuses on societal issues and a Major Qualifying Project (MQP) that focuses on major related research. Recently, WPI partnered and signed articulation agreements with more community colleges such as Middlesex Community College and Manchester Community College, that will provide expanded pathways for future community college transfer students to receive education at WPI. Moreover, these collaborations will further impact the development of talented diverse workforce and the regional economic growth.

 


Last Modified: 08/13/2024
Modified by: Izabela R Stroe

The goal of the Renewable Energy Materials Scholars STEM (REMS-STEM) Program at Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI), was to recruit, retain, and support low-income, academically talented, underrepresented students who transfer from two-year institutions of higher education (i.e., community colleges) to WPI, to complete a bachelors degree in the field of renewable energy materials.


The key objectives of the REMS-STEM program were:


(1) A 90% two-year graduation rate (18/20 REMS-STEM scholars), compared to the average 2-year graduation rate for transfer students of 33%.


(2) Ensuring that the remaining REMS-STEM scholars that do not graduate in two years will graduate in their third year, making a 3-year graduation rate of 100% vs. the current average 74%.


(3) Increasing the level of socioeconomic and racial diversity among students at WPI.


(4) Improving the probability that a REMS-STEM graduate will attain employment in a clean-energy technology field or continue their education at the graduate level.


Key Results of the REMS-STEM program:


(1) Recruited 21 (initially 20 total were proposed) low-income, academically talented, underrepresented students mainly from our two-year partner community collegesQuinsigamond Community College (QCC) and Mount Wachusett Community College (MWCC) to pursue a bachelors degree at WPI with a focus on renewable energy.

(4) Enhanced career sustainability of REMS-STEM scholars through their enrollment in graduate studies (MS and PhD) at WPI and elsewhere, and in career opportunities through industry partnerships in a clean energy technology field.


The results were actively disseminated by the PI and CO-PIs at national and international conferences and students involved in research presented their results at national conferences and were part of peer review publication authorship. All students completed two major projects at WPI with full/partial concentration on clean energy, an Intermediate Qualifying Project (IQP) that focuses on societal issues and a Major Qualifying Project (MQP) that focuses on major related research. Moreover, these collaborations will further impact the development of talented diverse workforce and the regional economic growth.
